During the Colts' 23-8 playoff victory against the Kansas City Chiefs on Saturday, Addai showed he could respond to postseason pressure, rushing for 122 yards on 25 carries and scoring the Colts' first touchdown, on a 6-yard run.  Some would call Addai a surprise. His coach, Tony Dungy, and the Colts' president, Bill Polian, do not.  ''We knew it was going to be a good draft for running backs,'' Dungy said during his news conference Sunday. ''We felt pretty confident that we would be able to get a good back in the first round. We liked Maroney, we liked Maurice Drew, we liked DeAngelo Williams, we liked Joseph. We felt like we were going to get one of those backs, and they all would bring something to the table. But honestly, when you look at everything that we do, Joseph was most like Edgerrin of all of those guys.  ''We had a long debate the night before the draft: If everybody was there, who would we take? Bill was really a Joseph Addai guy. We felt good that our running back situation was going to be in good hands.''  The Colts made a shrewd draft-day decision, considering that Addai never rushed for more than 1,000 yards during any college season. His best season came as a senior, when he ran for 911 yards. Sharing carries with other running backs kept him from amassing more impressive numbers.  Since arriving in Indianapolis, Addai has had little trouble impressing teammates. Addai picked up the Colts' complicated offensive system quickly, tutored by the veteran running back Dominic Rhodes.  After Saturday's game, Manning said: ''He and Dominic have allowed us to run the same plays and be as complex with our offense and our system as we have been in the nine years that I have been here. That is a real credit to both guys, especially a rookie running back.''  A 23-year-old native of Houston, Addai fits into the Colts' low-key locker room. He is quiet and defers to offensive stars like Manning and wide receiver Marvin Harrison.  Addai acknowledged that he was nervous before his first playoff game, but he handled the pressure well.  ''Before the game I was pretty amped up, but when the game started, I settled and was able to relax,'' he said.  Addai had leg cramps during the fourth quarter, but he said he did not expect any lingering problems.  ''Coach Dungy does real good in saving our bodies in practice,'' Addai said. ''I try to take advantage of that.''  During the regular season, Dungy started Rhodes and brought Addai into the game off the bench. But on Saturday, Dungy played a hunch and started Addai.  ''We just felt like this was the time to do it,'' Dungy said. ''We wanted to get some runs early in the game. I think we'll do the same thing this week. It worked pretty well for us.''  Dungy acknowledged that it might be harder for Addai to rush for 100 yards against the Ravens, the Colts' next playoff opponent, Saturday in Baltimore.  ''They play very aggressive, they load the box up, they want not to allow you to run,'' Dungy said of the Ravens. ''We've got to find ways to run. But we'll need to make big plays in the passing game.''  With Addai in the backfield, however, the Colts have a running game that must be respected. Manning is still the catalyst who powers the offense, but Addai is emerging as someone who can carry the running game.  ''We never felt any time that I've been here that our running game wasn't going to be good,'' Dungy said. ''Dominic and Joseph have done a great job all year. We just never really worried about that. You have to be able to run in the postseason. And when people give us looks like we got yesterday, when they were really trying to take away the deep passing game, we feel very confident that we're going to be able to run.''  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: Addai Moves Colts' Backfield to Forefront of the Offense

content.text: The Mets signed the journeyman catcher Mike DiFelice to a minor league contract yesterday. DiFelice, 37, was added to the Mets' major league roster in August when the backup catcher Ramon Castro went on the disabled list because of a sore left rib cage. In 15 games with the Mets, DiFelice batted .080. Castro returned for the playoffs, and DiFelice was left off the postseason roster.  MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT  SPORTS BRIEFING: BASEBALL
content.title: MINOR LEAGUE DEAL FOR DIFELICE

content.text: At halftime Sunday, the score was not knotted, but running back Brian Westbrook's stomach was. The cramps would not dissipate, but neither would Westbrook's determination to keep playing.  As the Giants' Tiki Barber was preparing to retire, Westbrook came into playoff prominence for Philadelphia. He skittered 49 yards for a second-quarter touchdown, then rushed for four first downs on the Eagles' final drive to set up the winning 38-yard field goal in a 23-20 victory.  ''I wasn't feeling very good,'' Westbrook said of his intestinal discomfort after rushing 20 times for 141 yards. But, he added, ''I wouldn't miss being out there.''  Much of his success came on what Philadelphia calls an outside zone play. Right tackle Jon Runyan seals off the inside, and fullback Thomas Tapeh occupies the outside linebacker, leaving Westbrook one on one with a safety or another linebacker. On the final drive in particular, Runyan said, the Giants kept blitzing and Westbrook ran right through the blitz.  ''You have to get positive yards on first down,'' Runyan said. ''It makes it easy for you. The defense doesn't know what you are doing. I don't think we had a third down on that drive until the field goal.''  It was hard to imagine it after Westbrook ran through and around the Giants, but there have long been questions here about him. Not about his ability to run or catch the ball, but about his ability to stay healthy.  Philadelphia threw the football at a rate unmatched in N.F.L. history -- 58.4 percent of the time -- in Coach Andy Reid's eighth season in Philadelphia. The main reason was the lively arm of quarterback Donovan McNabb. But, many suspect, Reid also did not trust that Westbrook could stay healthy enough to carry a punishing load at running back.  In any case, desperation forced Reid's hand.  When McNabb tore a ligament in his knee in November, the Eagles tore up their game plan. Lost was their big-play passing attack. To protect the replacement quarterback, Jeff Garcia, the Eagles grew somewhat cautious. Balance replaced ostentation.  Philadelphia began running as much as it passed in winning five consecutive games to end the regular season and to win the National Football Conference East. And the Eagles kept running during Sunday's wild-card playoff victory against the Giants.  ''He was very patient, and let things develop in front of him, and hit it,'' Reid said of Westbrook. ''It's not speed to the hole; it's speed through the hole. He's developed a good feel for that through the years.''  Before the game, Giants cornerback R. W. McQuarters compared Westbrook to a young Marshall Faulk, meaning that Westbrook was threatening and resourceful at both running and catching the ball. It was no hyperbole. Westbrook led all N.F.L. running backs this season by averaging 6 yards a touch.  ''Brian Westbrook is one of the few elite players in this league,'' said Marty Mornhinweg, the Eagles' offensive coordinator.  On Sunday, Westbrook also returned punts, and sliced through a porous Giants coverage team for a 65-yard return to the end zone that was nullified by a penalty for an illegal block in the back.  But Westbrook's most impressive achievement this season has been running the ball. He gained a career-high 1,217 yards in the regular season and became the first Eagle to rush for at least 1,000 yards while averaging 5 yards a carry.  Until now, there has been frequent and legitimate concern about his durability at 5 feet 8 inches, 203 pounds. He missed the playoffs after the 2003 season with a torn triceps tendon in his left arm. A year ago, his season ended prematurely because of a sprained foot. Earlier this season, Westbrook was bothered by a balky knee, and rumors spread here -- inaccurately -- that he might need surgery.  But he has been resilient and reliable since McNabb became injured, averaging about seven more carries a game.  ''It's a percentage thing,'' Runyan said of Westbrook. ''You give it to him, and he's going to do something with it. He's staying healthy and we're seeing what the guy can do.''  After the Eagles struggled early on Sunday, Westbrook sprinted around the right side from the Giants' 49-yard line early in the second quarter. Defensive end Adrian Awasom dived at Westbrook's feet, but could not bring him down. Safety Will Demps's effort was also futile, as Westbrook stutter-stepped one way, then went the other, jogging into the end zone to tie the score at 7-7.  Then, on the final drive, he exhausted the clock, and the Giants' chances.  ''It was a critical situation, and big-time players step up when you need them the most,'' Westbrook said.  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: In Despair, Eagles Turn to Westbrook to Help Carry Them

content.text: Tom Brady has an impeccable reputation for postseason heroics. But when the Colts beat the Patriots in November, Brady threw four interceptions. And when the Patriots beat the Chargers last week, Brady was picked off three times.  The conclusion?  ''He will throw you some,'' Colts cornerback Nick Harper said. ''No quarterback is perfect. If you have great coverage, sometimes he tends to throw the ball into coverage. I guess he feels like all his receivers are better than the defensive backs. He will throw the ball into coverage. We watched the New England game. He threw a lot of balls to the opposing team, but they didn't catch them.''  Brady and the Patriots, who will face the Colts at the RCA Dome in the A.F.C. championship game Sunday, have beaten the Colts twice recently in the playoffs: in the A.F.C. title game in Foxborough after the 2003 season, and in a second-round game the next year. But the Colts have won regular-season games the past two years.  Brady's play in the November loss was particularly uncharacteristic. It was a low point in a season in which Brady and his revamped corps of receivers struggled to find a chemistry, something that has come together only in recent weeks. Brady threw for 24 touchdowns and 12 interceptions in the regular season; he never threw more than two interceptions in any other game.  Still, Harper's harsh assessment is likely to find its way to a New England bulletin board this week. His comments stood out on a day when the Colts hewed to the company line that past performance meant nothing in the rivalry.  Brady's postseason record is beyond reproach; he is 12-1 in playoff games, losing only to the Broncos last season. But Harper said he thought Brady's recent struggles against the Indianapolis might be a sign that Colts were planted firmly in his head.  ''I would think so,'' Harper said. ''He knows if he makes a mistake, we're good enough to take advantage of it.''  JUDY BATTISTA  PRO FOOTBALL: PLAYOFF ROUNDUP
content.title: Colts Confident Against Pats

content.text: Veteran Softie  Sentimental would probably be the last word anyone would use to describe Bill Belichick, but for the second season in a row he gave one of his veteran players a very public farewell gift.  Last season it was allowing the retiring Doug Flutie to convert an extra point with a drop kick in the season finale. On Sunday against the Titans, he inserted Vinny Testaverde, above, the Patriots' third-string quarterback, with less than three minutes remaining so that he could try to throw a touchdown pass for a 20th consecutive season. Testaverde, who had previously played for Belichick with the Browns and the Jets, found Troy Brown for a 6-yard touchdown with 1 minutes 45 seconds left.  Testaverde, 43, and Brown, 35, have the oldest combined ages for players connecting on an N.F.L. touchdown pass, according to the Elias Sports Bureau.  While Belichick pumped his fists and the Patriots ran to congratulate Testaverde, some of the Titans were fuming. The score increased the Patriots' lead to 40-23. Titans defensive tackle Albert Haynesworth told reporters: ''To bring in a 50-year-old guy to throw a little pass, probably the last pass of his career or of his life, I don't know. Whatever.''  Nice Job, Kid  While Vinny Testaverde was striking a blow for the older generation Sunday, Jets Coach Eric Mangini was joining a different elite subset.  According to the Elias Sports Bureau, since the 1970 A.F.L.-N.F.L. merger, only two coaches younger than Mangini, 35, have led a team to the playoffs: John Madden (twice, at 33 and 34) and Bill Cowher (35).  Mangini and Testaverde may renew acquaintances when the Jets face the Patriots on Sunday. When Testaverde was the starting quarterback for Cleveland in 1984, Mangini, then 13, was breaking into the league as a Browns ball boy.  Thinking Big  Lost amid the record-breaking seasons of LaDainian Tomlinson and Larry Johnson, San Francisco running back Frank Gore broke the 49ers' franchise record with 1,695 rushing yards. He finished third in the N.F.L. and was named to his first Pro Bowl. But he has bigger plans for next season.  ''I'm going for 2,200 next year,'' Gore told reporters as he cleared out his locker Monday. ''That's the record, isn't it? Yeah, I'll get that.''  That would be Eric Dickerson's single-season record of 2,105 yards, set in 15 games in 1984.  Early Checkout  The consolation for Tom Walsh when he was dismissed as the Raiders' offensive coordinator in November was that he could return to the bed-and-breakfast he had run in Idaho. Oakland players like Randy Moss and Jerry Porter remained stuck in their own version of ''Hotel California'' -- they could check out but never leave.  Walsh had been out of the league since 1994, when he was Art Shell's offensive coordinator in Shell's first stint as Raiders coach. When Walsh rejoined Shell this season and installed his old-school offense of long-developing pass plays, the criticism began mounting.  A few days before the season, Moss said, ''Things are so fishy and question mark around here.'' In September, the former Raiders receiver Tim Brown said Walsh's offense was outdated even in the 1990s, calling it horrible and one-dimensional.  In November, quarterback Andrew Walter said the playbook lacked depth. He was promptly benched.  The result was the league's worst offense, which scored 12 touchdowns, or 72 points, in 16 games. By comparison, the Chargers' LaDainian Tomlinson scored 186 points.  A.F.C. Has Its Way  A.F.C. teams had a 40-24 record against N.F.C. teams during the regular season. Three were 4-0, all of them playoff teams -- New England, San Diego and Kansas City. Over all, A.F.C. playoff teams were 21-3 against the N.F.C. in the regular season. More specifically, A.F.C playoff teams were 6-2 against N.F.C playoff teams. N.F.C. playoff teams were 10-14 against A.F.C. teams, with the Giants faring the best at 3-1.  It Wasn't Luck, He Says  Coach Herman Edwards bristled when reporters suggested that the Chiefs were lucky to qualify for the playoffs. ''We didn't luck our way into it,'' Edwards told The Associated Press on Monday. ''We won our way into it, just like those other teams had to win their way into it. And they didn't do it, to be quite honest.''  The Chiefs (9-7) were the beneficiaries of an unlikely series of events. As Edwards famously said when he was Jets coach, ''You play to win the game.''  But it sure helps when everyone else that matters loses theirs.  The Chiefs first had to hand the Jaguars, who were also contending for a playoff spot, their third straight loss, which they did, 35-30.  Next, they needed the Broncos, the Titans and the Bengals to lose at home. The Broncos lost with less than two minutes left in overtime on a 36-yard field goal. The Titans lost after trailing by 3 points going into the fourth quarter. And the Bengals, who also lost in overtime, missed a game-winning field goal at the end of regulation.  Long-Armed Lion  Jon Kitna had 4,208 passing yards this season for the 3-13 Lions, the 30th time in the past 10 seasons that a quarterback has topped 4,000 yards. But Kitna is only the fifth player in that span to do it for a losing team.  The others are Jeff Garcia (4,278 for the 6-10 49ers in 2000), Elvis Grbac (4,164 for the 7-9 Chiefs in 2000), Peyton Manning (4,131 for the 6-10 Colts in 2001) and Trent Green (4,594 for the 7-9 Chiefs in 2004).  The 306-yard performance by Kitna against Dallas on Sunday could have, at least temporarily, saved his job. The win put the Lions behind the Raiders for the top pick in the 2007 draft and may have put Notre Dame quarterback Brady Quinn out of reach.  Extra Points  With the Eagles, the Cowboys and the Giants in the playoffs, this is the first time since realignment in 2002 that three teams from the same division have reached the postseason. The last time that happened was 2001, when three teams from the A.F.C. East (New England, Miami and the Jets) and the N.F.C. Central (Chicago, Tampa Bay and Green Bay) made the playoffs.  Shaun Alexander extended his league record for games with at least one 10-yard run to 64, a span of more than four full seasons.  PRO FOOTBALL  Correction:  January 9, 2007, Tuesday  A report in the Fifth Down football roundup on Thursday about the American Football Conference's dominance over the National Football Conference during the regular season misstated the N.F.C. playoff team that had the best record (3-1) against A.F.C. teams. It is the Dallas Cowboys -- not the Giants, who were 1-3.
content.title: THE FIFTH DOWN

content.text: Three years ago Monday, Lovie Smith was named to succeed Dick Jauron as the Chicago Bears' head coach. This year, the anniversary of his hiring coincided with the day set aside to remember the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.  The confluence of the two events on the calendar seemed fitting considering Smith is one of two African-American coaches whose teams are among the four left in the N.F.L. playoffs. The Indianapolis Colts' Tony Dungy is the other. ''I hope for a day when it is unnoticed,'' said Smith, referring to his skin color. ''That day isn't here. This is the first time that two black men have led their teams to the final four. You have to acknowledge that.''  Smith, the first man to lead the Bears to the postseason in two of the first three seasons of a coaching reign, and Mike Ditka are the only coaches in team history to repeat as division winners. At 13-3, the Bears finished with the best record in the National Football Conference.  Smith came to Chicago from St. Louis, where he was the defensive coordinator for three seasons.  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: Bears' Coach Notes a Milestone

content.text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 18 -- If the New England Patriots beat the Indianapolis Colts and advance to the Super Bowl, it will be a milestone for their 43-year-old backup quarterback, Vinny Testaverde, who has never reached the Super Bowl in 20 N.F.L. seasons.  "Every year I watch it, I think, 'Got away from me again,' " Testaverde said. "Hopefully, this year will be a little different."  The chance to win the Super Bowl, and another chance to play for Bill Belichick, lured Testaverde out of a brief retirement when he signed with the Patriots on Nov. 14 as a backup to Tom Brady. Testaverde's main role is to offer advice and encouragement as a stable presence in a locker room already loaded with experience.  The quarterback duel between Brady and Peyton Manning will be a dominant theme during Sunday's American Football Conference championship game, and Brady has the upper hand, with three Super Bowl titles and two playoff victories over Manning.  Because of those losses, and his failure to reach the Super Bowl, Manning has been targeted for criticism despite a brilliant career. But Testaverde finds it hard to fathom that Manning does not have the makeup to lead a team to a championship,  "I don't know Peyton personally as well as I do Tom, but I think from what I've seen, he has a lot of the same instincts and ability as Tom does," Testaverde said. "He's obviously one of the best. A lot of people don't give him as much credit as he deserves, because he hasn't won the big game yet. It's more than one player when it comes to winning in this sport. A guy as good as he is, sooner or later, he's going to get one, he's going to get a ring."  Though Testaverde barely played this season, a personal high point occurred Dec. 31, when he threw a touchdown pass to Troy Brown during the Patriots' 40-23 victory over Tennessee. The pass was completed with less than two minutes left in the game, and some Titans were not happy. But Belichick wanted Testaverde to become the first N.F.L. player to throw touchdown passes in 20 consecutive seasons, and Testaverde appreciated the opportunity.  "I didn't expect to go in the game at that point, and then when I did, I really didn't think we were going to be throwing the football," Testaverde said. "That situation shows that he does have a sense of history. He lets the team know the accomplishments of certain guys, because guys are proud to be a part of it, too."  Even if the Patriots win the Super Bowl, Testaverde did not guarantee that he would retire -- again.  "This is what I love to do," he said. "I can't think of anything better, and this is a great situation."  FOUR PATRIOTS ARE AILING At least four Patriots had flu symptoms Thursday, three days before New England takes on Indianapolis in the A.F.C. championship game.  Receiver Troy Brown, linebacker Tedy Bruschi, offensive tackle Ryan O'Callaghan and defensive tackle Mike Wright were ailing, but all were expected to be available for Sunday's game.  The hard-hitting safety Rodney Harrison, one of New England's key defensive players, was on the field at the beginning of Thursday's practice, although he missed the previous two playoff games with a knee injury. His status for Sunday was uncertain. Only the beginning of practice was open to the news media, so it was not known how much Harrison participated.
content.title: After 20 Seasons, Testaverde Has a Shot at First Super Bowl

content.text: A season of adversity for the Seattle Seahawks fittingly ended with frustration.  Robbie Gould's 49-yard field goal in overtime Sunday gave the Chicago Bears a 27-24 victory and ended the Seahawks' bid to repeat as the National Football Conference champions. A season ago, Seattle rolled to the conference's best record and reached the Super Bowl. But this season was filled with obstacles.  Many important players missed time with injuries, including quarterback Matt Hasselbeck and running back Shaun Alexander. The departure of left guard Steve Hutchinson to Minnesota via free agency hurt Seattle's running game. Finally, after escaping last week with a 1-point victory against Dallas in their playoff opener, the Seahawks ran out of answers here.  Just like last season, when the Seahawks felt demoralized after losing to Pittsburgh in the Super Bowl, their locker room was filled with quiet players with dejected faces.  ''This will be one that we think about for a long time,'' Hasselbeck said. ''I guess this just isn't our year. Last year, things came easier for us. Very few guys got hurt, our offensive line was healthy all season, everything was easier. This year was more like what most teams go through. But I'm proud of this team, the way we kept fighting.''  Seattle became the first Super Bowl loser since the 1999 Tennessee Titans to make the playoffs the next season. Sunday's loss, however, was filled with missed opportunities. They had the ball first in overtime but could not score. And on the ensuing punt, Ryan Plackemeier's 18-yard kick failed to pin down the Bears and gave them the ball at their 34 for the final drive.  Plackemeier said he rushed the punt when he was pressured.  ''I've got to learn to trust my protection,'' he said. ''A bad punt in that situation is not what we need.''  Early in the game, Seattle squandered another chance. On Chicago's opening drive, a pass by Bears quarterback Rex Grossman deflected off the hands of defensive back Jordan Babineaux and into the arms of Chicago's Rashied Davis for a 37-yard gain. Three plays later, the Bears scored a touchdown to take the lead, and Grossman's confidence was boosted.  How would Grossman have reacted if his pass had been intercepted by Babineaux on the game's opening drive? The Seahawks will never know, but Babineaux could not get that play out of his mind.  ''The ball slipped right through my hands,'' said Babineaux, who was also beaten in overtime when Davis made a 30-yard reception that helped set up Gould's winning field goal. ''A lot of people didn't think we should be here, but we knew we could line up and play with anybody.''  With Hasselbeck and Alexander returning, Seattle has the nucleus to be a contender for several seasons. But that did not ease the pain.  ''The finality of losing a playoff game this week hurts,'' Seahawks Coach Mike Holmgren said. ''I hope down the road, we get a few more cracks at this thing.''  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: Seahawks' Season Is Marked By Loss

content.text: The long path to respect and recognition was about to be completed by Louisville. The Cardinals had only recently raised their national profile with the move to the Big East from Conference USA two seasons ago, and the Orange Bowl on Tuesday night at Dolphin Stadium was to be the final step in Louisville's ascension to the short list of national contenders for next season.  If only the No. 5 Cardinals could beat a Wake Forest team dismissed by some as an opportunistic champion in a down year for the Atlantic Coast Conference.  The No. 15 Demon Deacons, accustomed to being underrated and underestimated, made it much harder than Louisville fans might have preferred. But in the end, the Cardinals earned their place with a 24-13 victory against Wake Forest in front of 74,470 in the first Bowl Championship Series game for these programs on the rise.  In a game defined by defense through most of three quarters, it was the offenses that finally took over in the fourth. And that was why high-powered Louisville won. Cardinals quarterback Brian Brohm, the game's most valuable player, directed an eight-play, 81-yard drive that was capped by a 1-yard touchdown run by Anthony Allen with 12 minutes 31 seconds remaining to give the Cardinals a 17-13 lead.  Brohm completed 24 of 34 for 312 yards, third most in Orange Bowl history behind Tom Brady of Michigan and Matt Leinart of Southern California.  ''Just to be mentioned with those guys' names is a special thing,'' Brohm said.  Brock Bolen added an 18-yard touchdown run with 4:55 remaining to seal the victory for Louisville (12-1). The Cardinals could begin next season among the leading contenders for the national championship if Brohm and the injured running back Michael Bush return instead of entering the N.F.L. draft.  After the game, fans chanted ''One more year!'' and Brohm said, ''Right now, coming back and trying to win the national title is very appealing.''  Wake Forest (11-3) completed its best season in team history with the A.C.C. championship and its first 11-win season.  ''I told the kids in the locker room after the game to be really proud of what we've accomplished,'' Wake Forest Coach Jim Grobe said. ''It's funny. You get in the Orange Bowl and being in the Orange Bowl feels really, really good. But when you lose, it doesn't feel any different than when you lose any other time.''  The game was not the offensive barrage that Louisville fans had come to expect from a Cardinals team that came in scoring 38.9 points a game. Wake Forest, with a defense that posted a 30-0 shutout at Florida State earlier in the season and advanced to the Orange Bowl with a 9-6 victory over Georgia Tech in the A.C.C. title game, would not have it.  Indeed, it took a trick play for the Cardinals to take a 10-3 lead at halftime. And Wake Forest erased that deficit on its first drive of the second half, when Riley Skinner completed a 30-yard touchdown pass to a wide-open Nate Morton three and a half minutes into the third quarter to tie the score at 10-10. It was the first touchdown in six quarters for the Demon Deacons, dating to a victory at Maryland on Nov. 25.  Wake Forest appeared on its way to taking the lead later in the quarter, but running back Rich Belton fumbled at the Louisville 14-yard line.  After a scoreless first quarter, Wake Forest took the first lead when Sam Swank kicked a 44-yard field goal 43 seconds into the second quarter. How dominant were the defenses? The score came after a Demon Deacons drive that went exactly one yard. Wake Forest had gained the field position on what appeared to be a partly blocked punt that went just 14 yards and gave the Demon Deacons the ball on Louisville's 28. This came after a first quarter in which Wake Forest was held to 24 total yards of offense, including minus-27 yards rushing.  Still, the Demon Deacons were in the game because Louisville's offense was not much more productive. The Cardinals totaled 34 yards in the opening quarter, with the highly touted Brohm managing just 8 yards on 2-of-4 passing.  A poor punt by Swank set up the lone touchdown of the first half. It came on an option pass from wide receiver Patrick Carter, a former quarterback, who took a lateral from Brohm near the right sideline and threw across the field to an open Allen on the far side of the field. He easily ran in for the 21-yard touchdown reception and a 10-3 Louisville lead with 5:53 to go in the half.  Although there has been much speculation about Brohm's future and the possibility he could pass up his senior season and enter the N.F.L. draft, it was a redshirt freshman, Skinner, who put up more impressive numbers in the first half. Skinner was 10 of 13 for 124 yards; Brohm was 7 of 13 for 79 yards.  Skinner finished 21 of 33 for 272 yards with a touchdown and an interception.  FOOTBALL
content.title: Louisville Hoping Big Finish Carries Over to Next Season

content.text: It's decision time for the Giants' president, John Mara, and the Tisch brothers, Steve, the team chairman, and Jonathan, the treasurer:  To support or sack Tom Coughlin as coach. To name a general manager to replace the retiring Ernie Accorsi.  For all the commotion in recent weeks over Coughlin's future and despite the Giants' gallant 23-20 loss to the Eagles yesterday in the opening round of the Super Bowl XLI playoffs, the thinking here is that Coughlin deserves to stay as the coach and that Jerry Reese, the director of player personnel, should be anointed as the general manager.  When the injury-depleted Giants tumbled into a 1-6 tailspin before salvaging an 8-8 record and a wild card, yes, Coughlin was the coach. But until that streak, Coughlin was the coach of mostly healthy Giants teams that over the 2005 season and half of this season were 17-7, not including a 23-0 loss to Carolina in the playoffs a year ago.  When Mara (who has one vote as co-owner) and the Tisch brothers (who have one vote between them representing their co-ownership) sit down to judge Coughlin, they need to remember that 17-7 run when the Giants were mostly healthy, not just the 1-6 tailspin.  Mara and the Tisch brothers also need to remember that, whatever the eventual playoff disappointments, under Coughlin the Giants qualified for the playoffs in consecutive seasons. That had not happened since the 1989 and 1990 teams in Bill Parcells's last two years as the Giants' coach.  Mara and the Tisch brothers also need to ask themselves: If we dismiss Coughlin, is an obvious successor available?  The popular candidate would be Charlie Weis, the Notre Dame coach who made his reputation as the Patriots' offensive coordinator and sculptor of quarterback Tom Brady. But before Notre Dame's 41-14 loss to Louisiana State on Wednesday in the Sugar Bowl, Weis insisted that he intended to stay in South Bend until his son Charlie, an eighth grader, graduates from Notre Dame.  As the Dolphins learned when Nick Saban accepted the University of Alabama job, coaches can, and have, often changed their minds about going elsewhere, but seldom does a coach, as a father, link a son to the timetable of his future.  As a coach, Weis also has much to prove. Over his two seasons at Notre Dame, he has produced a 19-6 record, but two of those losses were in Bowl Championship Series games, to Ohio State a year ago and to L.S.U. last week. He acknowledged having a ''nice, solid team,'' but said that ''you want to be an upper-echelon team'' to compete for a national championship.  If the Giants' job were open, another people's choice would surely be Parcells, if he were to leave the Cowboys after Saturday night's painful 21-20 loss in Seattle on Tony Romo's botched field-goal hold. But at 65, Parcells may, finally, decide to stay retired. Then again, he has been known to change his mind.  Three years ago, Weis was interviewed for the Giants' job along with Lovie Smith, now the Bears' coach, and Romeo Crennel, now the Browns' coach, as well as Coughlin -- in retrospect a formidable foursome. Coughlin was at liberty, having been out of football for a year after his firing at Jacksonville. He had quickly molded the expansion Jaguars into a four-time playoff team before sagging to a 6-10 record in each of his final two seasons.  Although some new assistants will probably join Coughlin's staff, the Giants don't need a new head coach as much as they need a running back who will approach the yardage supplied by the retiring Tiki Barber, a more accurate and more assertive Eli Manning at quarterback and a dominating pass-rusher to replace the battered Michael Strahan. They also need healthy comebacks from season-ending injuries to wide receiver Amani Toomer and linebacker LaVar Arrington.  As for the identity of the new general manager, who will be responsible for acquiring new and better players, three candidates besides Reese, all in the front office, have been interviewed: Chris Mara, the vice president for player evaluation; Kevin Abrams, the assistant general manager; and Dave Gettleman, the director of pro personnel.  If it takes one to know one, Accorsi, who was hired by George Young as his successor, has recommended Reese to be his successor.  Chris Mara, who is John's younger brother, is certainly qualified as a longtime Giants scout as well as an Arena Football League team general manager, but choosing him would open the Giants to complaints of nepotism. It would also make Chris Mara a possible target for change after losing seasons. If he retains his current title, he will continue to have as much input on player evaluation, for free agents and draft choices, without a bull's-eye on his back.  But those decisions on the coach and the general manager are for John Mara and the Tisch brothers to make. And make quickly. With the scouting combine only a few weeks away, next season is about to begin.  SPORTS OF THE TIMES
content.title: There's More To Consider Than a Tailspin

content.text: For a trip to the Super Bowl, Bill Belichick and Tony Dungy were willing to take chances.  Both Belichick and Dungy coached aggressively during Sunday's American Football Conference championship game. Belichick, the New England Patriots' coach, set the tone, giving his team early momentum by choosing to go for a first down, rather than punt, on two occasions during the first half. Both times, the Patriots made Belichick look good, converting the first down. And on both of those drives, the Patriots scored a touchdown.  The Patriots built a 21-3 lead and stayed aggressive throughout. Leading by 34-31 with 3 minutes 22 seconds remaining, they appeared to be going for the kill, rather than trying to kill the clock. They ran three straight passing plays and did not get a first down. New England was forced to punt after running only a minute off the clock.  The Colts scored 1:17 later, aided greatly by a roughing the passer penalty on Tully Banta-Cain, to win, 38-34.  Belichick's first gamble came less than seven minutes into the game, facing a fourth-and-1 from the Colts' 48-yard line. The game was still scoreless, and many coaches would have decided to punt, hoping to pin the Colts deep in their own territory.  Not Belichick, who has a penchant for becoming more aggressive during the playoffs, contrary to coaches who become more conservative. The Patriots made the first down with a huge play, when Corey Dillon ran through a gaping hole and rumbled 35 yards to the Colts' 13-yard line. Three plays later, the Patriots scored a weird touchdown, when offensive guard Logan Mankins recovered a fumble in the end zone after a wild scramble.  Leading by 7-3 early in the second quarter, Belichick gambled again with the Patriots facing fourth-and-6 from the Colts' 34. Belichick could have called for a punt, or for a long field-goal attempt by the rookie place-kicker Stephen Gostkowski. Instead, Belichick turned to quarterback Tom Brady, something he has done often.  ''I'll go back to another saying that I think would define my philosophy as a coach,'' Belichick said Thursday. ''In critical situations, think of players, not plays. I think a lot of coaches live by that motto. When it comes to a critical situation, you want your best playmakers critically involved in the play.''  On the fourth-and-6 play, Brady found a familiar target, wide receiver Troy Brown, running free in the middle of the field. The fourth-down pass play from Brady to Brown covered 27 yards, giving the Patriots first-and-goal at the 7. On the next play, Dillon rumbled into the end zone to give the Patriots a 14-3 edge.  But the Colts rallied, giving Dungy a chance to show his gambler's mentality. With just over four minutes remaining in the third quarter, Peyton Manning threw a 1-yard touchdown pass to defensive tackle Dan Klecko, who had come in on offense, to pull the Colts within 21-19, then Dungy called for a 2-point conversion. The Colts had more than a quarter to catch up, and they could have kicked an extra point to pull within a point.  But Dungy wanted to catch up immediately. His decision paid off, when Manning connected with Marvin Harrison in the end zone for the conversion, tying the score.  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: Coaches Bet in Big Spots, and Players Make Them Look Wise

content.text: The locker room was quiet, players spoke in hushed tones, and the New England Patriots felt as empty as many of their past victims.  This was an unfamiliar finish for the Patriots, losing an 18-point second-quarter lead and the American Football Conference championship game. Sunday's 38-34 victory by the Indianapolis Colts will be remembered as a classic playoff game, but for the Patriots, the second half was a nightmare.  They were shredded by Peyton Manning and the Indianapolis offense. They dropped passes. They committed key penalties. And in the end, quarterback Tom Brady ran out of magic and time.  Having won three Super Bowls in the past five seasons, the Patriots saw the opportunity to win another snatched away. There will be plenty of time for self-analysis. But immediately afterward, the prevailing feeling among the Patriots was disappointment.  ''It'll take a good while to swallow this one,'' said linebacker Tedy Bruschi, a member of the Patriots' three Super Bowl winners. ''I put so much into this season. I'm really emotional right now. This game was momentum swings on top of momentum swings. And theirs was the one that finished it.''  The Colts dissected New England's proud defense in the second half, scoring on five of seven second-half possessions, not counting the knee that Manning took to end the game. The Patriots could not stop the Colts when it counted most. They were protecting a 34-31 lead with 2 minutes 17 seconds to play, when Indianapolis regained possession on its 20.  From that point, Manning engineered a drive that will take its place in N.F.L. lore, moving the Colts 80 yards in seven plays for the winning touchdown, a 3-yard run by Joseph Addai.  Uncharacteristically, the Patriots surrendered yardage in chunks during that decisive drive. Manning completed a 32-yard pass to Bryan Fletcher and another for 14 yards to Reggie Wayne.  On that play, Patriots defensive end Tully Banta-Cain was penalized for roughing the passer, moving the ball from New England's 23-yard line to the 11 with 1:53 left.  Without that penalty, perhaps the Colts would have settled for a tying field goal that would probably have forced overtime. Instead, the Colts called Addai's number on three consecutive running plays, the final one resulting in a touchdown.  That left the Patriots trailing by 4 points with 54 seconds and two timeouts remaining. when they took over at their 21.  Even for Brady, this was a nearly impossible situation. Four plays later, he tried to force a pass to Ben Watson that was intercepted by Marlin Jackson with 16 seconds to play. Indianapolis could celebrate. The Patriots could reflect.  ''We just let too many opportunities slip away,'' said Brady, who completed 21 of 34 passes, for 232 yards and a touchdown. ''The last pass, you're just trying to force it, make a play. In hindsight, you probably should throw it away. But time was an issue.  ''It's frustrating for all of us when it ends like this, because the expectations are high. We just have to come back next year and try to do it better.''  The Patriots appeared to have the Colts on the run in the second quarter, after New England defensive back Asante Samuel cut in front of a pass intended for Marvin Harrison and returned the ball 39 yards for a touchdown. The extra point gave the Patriots a 21-3 lead, and they stopped Indianapolis on its next drive.  But after reaching the Colts' 27, the Patriots committed back-to-back penalties and eventually punted.  That gave the Colts a chance to regroup, and they managed a 12-play drive for a field goal that pulled them to 21-6 at halftime.  In the second half, the Colts' offensive machine clicked, and the Patriots at times looked tired and a step slow.  ''They're a high-powered offense,'' Patriots linebacker Mike Vrabel said. ''We knew the game wasn't over.''  Asked if he was disappointed that the Patriots could not generate more of a pass rush against Manning, defensive end Ty Warren said: ''You not only have to get to him, you have to get to him quick. They run timing patterns. If you don't get there, the ball is gone.''  The Patriots had a chance to run out the clock, getting the ball with 3:32 left and leading by 34-31. But they were stopped after three plays, giving Manning the opportunity to orchestrate his final drive.  So instead of going to another Super Bowl, Brady will be watching it. Or will he?  ''Knowing me, probably not,'' Brady said. ''Probably not.''  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: In Role Reversal, New England Fades With Game on the Line

content.text: Kicking and scheming, 8 of the N.F.L.'s 12 playoff teams will be in action this weekend in back-to-back doubleheaders.  KANSAS CITY AT INDIANAPOLIS  4:30 p.m., NBC  DALLAS AT SEATTLE  8 p.m., NBC  TODAY -- The games include a team that was in last year's Super Bowl (the Seahawks), a team that can't seem to get to the Super Bowl (the Colts) and a coach (the Cowboys' Bill Parcells) who would like to get there one more time.  JETS AT NEW ENGLAND  1 p.m., CBS  GIANTS  AT PHILADELPHIA  4:30 p.m., Fox  TOMORROW -- The pairings feature division rivals, with the Jets trying to upset the Patriots for the second time this season and the slumping, but fortunate, Giants trying to justify their presence by surprising the Eagles.  PRO FOOTBALL

There is nothing subtle about Jeremy Shockey. His hair is surfer-dude blond, his arms are emblazoned with tattoos, and he barks at opponents and officials when things do not bounce his way.  Shockey's teammates would not change him one bit.  ''He's our emotional leader,'' center Shaun O'Hara said before practice Thursday. ''Sometimes for good, sometimes for bad. But you know you're going to get the same thing from him every time, and I love him for it. I wouldn't want anybody else out there.''  There is a chance the Giants will have to play with the backup tight end Visanthe Shiancoe instead of Shockey in Sunday's wild-card game in Philadelphia. Shockey, who practiced Thursday for the first time since injuring his left ankle against the New Orleans Saints on Dec. 24, was listed as questionable. Coach Tom Coughlin said Shockey was making progress.  When Shiancoe has started in place of Shockey, the Giants' offense has changed considerably. Shiancoe is widely regarded as a blocking tight end; Shockey led the team this season with 66 receptions.  But in terms of confidence and self-promotion, Shiancoe and Shockey appear to be on equal footing.  ''Look, man, I'm 6-5, 255 pounds,'' said Shiancoe, who is listed as 6-4 and 250 pounds in the Giants' media guide. ''I run a 4.5. I'm strong as -- excuse me -- hell. So I can basically do anything the coaches tell me to do, and they know that.''  He added, ''If Shockey is not able to go, of course I could get 100 yards.''  That would be a first. Shiancoe had a career-high 12 catches this season for 81 yards and no touchdowns. He has never caught a pass longer than 17 yards in his career.  But Shiancoe might be a better blocker than Shockey, who was selected to his fourth Pro Bowl this season. And he certainly seems to be more durable. Shiancoe has played in every game since being drafted by the Giants in the third round in 2003, while Shockey has missed 11 games in five seasons.  The swollen ankle forced Shockey to miss last Saturday's regular-season finale in Washington.  ''I just felt like I couldn't compete as hard as Visanthe Shiancoe and the other guys,'' Shockey said Wednesday when asked about not playing against the Redskins. ''They got an opportunity and they did very well.''  Shiancoe started in Washington and had 1 reception for 8 yards in the Giants' 34-28 victory. Tiki Barber rushed for a club-record 234 yards on 23 carries. Coincidence? Shiancoe said he did not think so, and he may have had a point. The Giants appeared to stick with the running game longer than they would have had Shockey been available.  The Giants also did not miss a beat when Shockey was limited by an injured right ankle at the start of the season. They won six of their first eight games with Shiancoe occasionally filling in. With Shockey sidelined in the overtime of the Giants' 30-24 victory in Philadelphia on Sept. 17, Shiancoe wrested away a 9-yard pass from safety Brian Dawkins, sustaining the game-winning drive.  But Shockey is clearly a better fit in the offense. When Barber was asked Tuesday about the impact Shockey's absence had in Washington, he said: ''We were forced to run the ball. It hurts our intermediate pass game, and this is not a slight on Shiancoe at all. But he's inexperienced in there.''  Barber, who ran for touchdowns of 15, 55 and 50 yards against the Redskins, added that Shiancoe was a good blocker.  ''I try to maul people, man,'' Shiancoe said about the subtleties of blocking. ''Tiki's all over the place, man. You don't know where he's going to go. And usually, for some reason, he follows behind me.''  Even if Shockey is healthy enough to play Sunday, Shiancoe will likely work up a sweat. He started three games in which the Giants opened with dual tight-end sets, and he is a fixture on special teams, playing on most kickoff returns and field-goal attempts.  But if Shockey is on the field, Shiancoe's role will be limited at best. Still, he insisted he was not bothered by being overshadowed by Shockey.  ''Everyone thinks that they're starters,'' Shiancoe said. ''Nobody wants their whole career to not be really a strong part of the offense. But it's my role here -- the backup tight end.''  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: Backup Tight End Can Talk the Shockey Talk

content.text: Laveranues Coles's face brightened when somebody mentioned the block he made to help spring running back Leon Washington on his 15-yard scoring run in the fourth quarter of the Jets' 23-3 victory against the Oakland Raiders.  ''I think that explains me totally,'' Coles said. ''I can go out and make all the catches in the world, but I think the most important things I do are the little things. I take more pride in blocking and watching other guys score and stuff like that than anything.''  Quarterback Chad Pennington threw to Coles twice unsuccessfully in the end zone, but on Sunday he was mostly used as a decoy, drawing double-teams to open the field for Jerricho Cotchery, who had 7 catches for 53 yards, and Justin McCareins, who caught 5 passes for 27 yards.  Coles had two catches to finish the regular season with a career-high 91, one more than he had in 2004 with the Washington Redskins. It was by design that Coles did not run many routes across the middle; the game plan was to keep him out of harm's way as much as possible. He was playing six days after sustaining a concussion in a helmet-to-helmet hit in the second quarter of the Jets' 13-10 victory at Miami.  Coles played the second half against the Dolphins but did not practice all week.  ''He's pretty banged up right now,'' Cotchery said. ''He's a warrior. To see him take the hit he took last week when he didn't know where he was at and come back to play today is amazing to me.''  Jets Coach Eric Mangini does not talk about injuries and has made it clear that he expects his players to follow his lead. Coles was asked repeatedly about the state of his health after the game and, per Mangini's edict, refused to comment.  ''Ask me about the playoffs,'' he said.  One reporter's persistent questioning about Coles's head injury led to a shouting match between the two that ended with two Jets employees stepping in to restrain them.  ''I'm sorry you had to see that,'' Coles said after cooling down.  Coles's toughness continues to impress Mangini, who said: ''He's different than other guys who say, 'I'm O.K. but. ' He says, 'I'm O.K.' He's so tough he doesn't give you anything.''  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: Pain Is Real; Coles's Role Is as a Decoy

content.text: The Arizona Diamondbacks took the next step toward completing a five-player trade with the Yankees yesterday, agreeing to a two-year contract with pitcher Randy Johnson, one of Johnson's agents, Alan Nero, said.  Johnson had one year and $16 million left on his previous contract. The new contract, which goes through the 2008 season, is worth $26 million, so it essentially serves as a one-year extension for about $10 million.  The Yankees included $2 million when they agreed to trade Johnson to the Diamondbacks on Thursday for the veteran right-handed reliever Luis Vizcaíno and three prospects.  Starting Thursday afternoon, Johnson and the Diamondbacks had a 72-hour window to negotiate a contract. The deal was completed before the window expired yesterday at 5 p.m. Eastern.  Johnson, 43, has 280 career victories and will probably need two more seasons to reach 300.  For the deal to become official, Johnson must pass a physical today and the trade must be approved by Commissioner Bud Selig because it involves the signing of a new contract.  Johnson had back surgery this off-season to repair a herniated disk. Nero said that Johnson should have no trouble passing the physical but that he was not sure if he would be ready to pitch by opening day.  If Johnson passes the physical, the Diamondbacks will probably have a news conference tomorrow to announce his return.  Johnson pitched for Arizona from 1999 to 2004, then was traded to the Yankees before the 2005 season.  In two uneven years in New York, Johnson had an uneasy relationship with the news media and posted the highest earned run average of his career (5.00 in 2006), though he won 17 games each season.  CAIRO TO RETURN -- The Yankees have come to terms on a one-year, $750,000 contract with infielder Miguel Cairo.  The deal to re-sign Cairo, first reported by The New York Post, should solidify the Yankees' infield for next season. In 81 games for the Yankees last season, Cairo batted .239 and played four infield positions and left field.  Cairo also played for the Yankees in 2004 and was a member of the Mets in 2005.  BASEBALL
content.title: Johnson Accepts Two-Year Offer

content.text: A sports article on Sunday about Indianapolis Colts Coach Tony Dungy gave the incorrect name in some copies of the city where one of his former assistants now coaches in the National Football League. Rod Marinelli is the head coach in Detroit, not Green Bay.
content.title: Corrections

content.text: The Florida Gators navigated their way through a grueling Southeastern Conference schedule, mastering the art of winning ugly.  They relied on a stout defense, a jury-rigged offense and a pinch of serendipity to reach the Bowl Championship Series title game Monday night.  But in a 41-14 mauling of top-ranked Ohio State, the No. 2 Gators left little to chance.  Led by the brilliance of the senior quarterback Chris Leak, the boundless creativity of the offensive coordinator Dan Mullen and the dominance of defensive end Derrick Harvey, Florida stunned college football by blowing the undefeated Buckeyes off the field.  The victory completed one of the most unlikely runs to the national title in recent college football history. Coach Urban Meyer's Gators grinded through the regular season with a collection of close victories, and they would not have made it here if Southern California had not been upset by U.C.L.A. on the regular season's final day.  But once they got here, the Gators (13-1) appeared undaunted. The victory secured their second national title in football, and it made Florida the first university to hold football and men's basketball national titles at the same time.  The Buckeyes (12-1) had the country's top defense, the Heisman Trophy winner in quarterback Troy Smith, and the nation's No. 1 ranking from the start of the season.  But this game proved to be a microcosm of their season, starting with a bang and ending with a thud. Ted Ginn Jr. returned the game's opening kickoff 93 yards for a touchdown. From that point, though, almost nothing went right for the Buckeyes.  Ohio State, which had not played since Nov. 18, set up Florida's first two touchdown drives with personal foul penalties, set up the next two with turnovers and never got Smith in rhythm.  Smith finished the game 4 of 14 for 35 yards, with an interception, and he had minus-29 yards rushing on 10 attempts. Ohio State had trailed after halftime just once during the regular season, and the Buckeyes never looked comfortable trying to scrape back from the 20-point halftime deficit.  ''They moved the ball down the field all season on tape,'' Florida cornerback Ryan Smith said, ''but when they saw our front four, they couldn't do anything about it.''  Troy Smith said: ''Not everything in life is going to go the exact way you want it. I don't have any regrets, though. I really don't. We came out and fought. We came up short.''  With all that dominance, there were a few dollops of good fortune for Florida. The oft-ridiculed place-kicker Chris Hetland, who had made only 4 of 13 field-goal attempts all season, knocked in first-half kicks from 42 and 40 yards. Also aiding Florida was a first-quarter ankle injury to Ginn, who said he was injured celebrating his touchdown. Ginn did not play the final three quarters and was on crutches in the second half.  But history will best remember the lopsided tenor of the game, which Leak set by leading near-flawless touchdown drives of 46, 34 and 71 yards on Florida's first three possessions. Leak's accuracy -- he completed his first nine passes and 25 of 36 for 212 yards and a touchdown -- combined with the ingenuity of Meyer's spread offense, led to the offensive onslaught.  Leak entered Florida as one of the nation's top high school recruits and was the starter midway through his freshman season. He had an up-and-down career, though, and he was forced to endure boos from the fans in Gainesville this season.  On Monday, he lived up to his advance billing.  ''He was unbelievable,'' said Mullen, the offensive coordinator. ''This is what he came here for. He came here to win championships, and that's what he did tonight.''  Ryan Smith said: ''A lot of people don't realize he's in the best league, playing against the best defense. He played great tonight.''  Three different players lined up at quarterback in Florida's first eight offensive snaps. The Gators used reverses, pitches to wide receivers and draw plays to keep Ohio State off balance.  Florida's four first-half touchdowns showcased its offensive diversity, as the Gators picked apart a defense that led the nation in scoring defense, allowing 10.4 points a game.  But Florida's scoring came early and often. The first touchdown, tying the score at 7-7, came when Leak threw a 14-yard pass to Dallas Baker, who beat Buckeyes corner Malcolm Jenkins thanks to a deft Leak pump fake. The next score came when Leak pitched to wide receiver Percy Harvin for a 4-yard touchdown run.  Florida took a 21-7 lead when tailback DeShawn Wynn muscled up the middle for a 2-yard run out of a strange formation with three running backs stacked up in a straight line. The backup quarterback Tim Tebow completed the first-half scoring when he threw a 1-yard touchdown to Andre Caldwell on a third-and-goal play.  That sent Ohio State into halftime trailing by 34-14 and left Mullen looking like a sideline wizard with his endless array of formations, presnap motions and near-flawless execution. (Leak's first three misses after hitting his first nine passes were intentional throwaways.)  Harvey, Florida's star sophomore defensive end, derailed two Ohio State drives with sacks of Smith that showcased his speed.  Harvey ran down Smith for a 7-yard loss on a third down during Ohio State's first offensive possession. On the Buckeyes' second possession, he warped the drive with a 10-yard sack on first down. That drive ended with an interception by Reggie Lewis on a third-and-14 after cornerback Ryan Smith blasted Troy Smith with a blitz.  Harvey added an exclamation point to his dominant first half when he recovered the ball after Jarvis Moss forced a Smith fumble. That gave Florida the ball on the Ohio State 5 and set up the final score of an astonishingly dominant half.  ''Honestly, we've played a lot better teams than them,'' Moss said. ''I could name four or five teams in the SEC that could probably compete with them and play the same type of game we did against them.''  Smith's fumble capped a miserable first half, as both his fumble and interception led to Gators scores. Six of the past seven Heisman Trophy winners who have played for the national title have now lost. Matt Leinart, who led U.S.C. to a blowout of Oklahoma in the 2004 B.C.S. title game, is the only exception.  Florida's only loss this season came in its seventh game, to Auburn, 27-17, on Oct. 14. They capped the regular season by beating Arkansas in the SEC title game on Dec. 2.  ''We became a better team every game as the season went on,'' Ryan Smith said. ''In the last game of the season, the national championship, we played our best game.''  A team that got to this game in the most improbable fashion put a thumping on the Buckeyes that even the widest-eyed Gators optimist could not have conceived.  And Monday night, Florida and Ohio State proved for this game and this season, that people do not remember how you start. They will only remember where you finish.  COLLEGE FOOTBALL
content.title: There's Nothing Ugly About a Title
